--- Kenneth Stanley <kstanley@...> wrote: 
> It's easy to delete a gene, see the nodes and
> genes, see the historical markings (the numbers 
> increasing  from 1 to 39 in the gens). The
> format also allows comments in C-style, so 
> genes can be commented out:
> 
> /* gene 1 10 16 0 0 36 0 1 */

All the same is true for XML, e.g.:

<neuron id="0" type="IN"/>
<neuron id="1" type="IN"/>
<neuron id="2" type="IN"/>
<neuron id="3" type="OUT"/>
<connection id="4" src-id="0" dest-id="3"
weight="-1.3731676929130425"/>
<connection id="5" src-id="1" dest-id="3"
weight="-1.208831769841949"/>
<connection id="6" src-id="2" dest-id="3"
weight="-0.853548931074944"/>

What you call a node, our XML calls a neuron.  What
you call a gene, our XML calls a connection. 
Historical markings are clearly defined by the id
attributes (though we assign neurons ids as well). 
And as Colin points out, XML can be commented out as
well.

As far as readability, XML is more reader-friendly, as
long as its schema is designed well.  For example:

gene 1 1 14 -0.242932 0 1 -0.242932 1

Unless I am familiar with the code, I'm not sure what
each of these values maps to.  I'm not sure why the
weight value is listed twice, etc.  This code is more
compact, but I think it is less human-readable.

But even so, again as Colin pointed out, it's fairly
trivial to write an XSL style sheet that converts
something that looks like:

<neuron id="0" type="IN"/>
<neuron id="1" type="IN"/>
<neuron id="2" type="IN"/>
<neuron id="3" type="OUT"/>
<connection id="4" src-id="0" dest-id="3"
weight="-1.3731676929130425"/>
<connection id="5" src-id="1" dest-id="3"
weight="-1.208831769841949"/>
<connection id="6" src-id="2" dest-id="3"
weight="-0.853548931074944"/>

...into something that looks like:

node 1 0 1 1
node 2 0 1 1
node 3 0 1 1
node 4 0 1 1
gene 1 1 14 -0.242932 0 1 -0.242932 1
gene 1 2 14 -0.665275 0 2 -0.665275 1
gene 1 3 14 -0.690939 0 3 -0.690939 1

An XSL style sheet iterates across XML tags and their
associated attributes, and spits out whatever you tell
it to.

> Anyway, XML has some great properties and uses, so
> I am not arguing against XML.  But what I think
> would be especially cool would be if there was
> a conversion function both ways between NEAT-XML 
> and NEAT-traditional genome styles.  

Yeah...but Colin's also right that XML ->
NEAT-traditional is easy, but NEAT-traditional -> XML
would require some code to translate it into workable
XML...though that really shouldn't be too awfully
difficult.  

Derek
